results.title: Joseph Brodsky Slept Here. The Great Poet’s Cranky Neighbor Couldn’t Care Less.
results.abstract: After a decades-long standoff with the last resident of a communal apartment, a private museum has finally opened in Brodsky’s shared home in St. Petersburg, a rare grass-roots victory in Russia.

multimedia.caption: The interior of the Joseph Brodsky Museum in St. Petersburg, Russia. The poet lived in the building with his parents until he fled the country in 1972.

results.title: ‘It’s a Godsend’: 9-Cent Taxi Rides in Rural South Korea
results.abstract: One county’s plan to help older, carless citizens stuck in remote villages proved wildly popular and has been copied across South Korea, revolutionizing public transportation in the countryside.

results.title: 20 Years On, the War on Terror Grinds Along, With No End in Sight
results.abstract: The failures in Iraq and Afghanistan obscure what experts say is the striking success of a multilateral effort that extends to as many as 85 countries.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

results.title: Times Investigation: In U.S. Drone Strike, Evidence Suggests No ISIS Bomb

results.title: Israel threatens to charge scores who returned from a Ukraine pilgrimage using faked coronavirus test results.
results.abstract: Officials said that more than 1,500 cases were identified among the 17,000 travelers who flew back on Thursday and Friday, and that more than 150 had hidden positive test results and obtained falsified negative results to travel on.

results.title: Denmark lifts the last of its coronavirus restrictions.
results.abstract: The country’s health minister said, “This can only be done because we have come a long way with the vaccination rollout, have a strong epidemic control, and because the entire Danish population has made an enormous effort to get here.”

results.title: Gilbert Seltzer, Soldier in the World War II ‘Ghost Army,’ Dies at 106
results.abstract: He was one of the last survivors of a band of Army con artists who duped German forces with their arsenal of fakery, including inflatable tanks and scripted radio transmissions.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces
The Ghost Army of World War II: How One Top-Secret Unit Deceived the Enemy with Inflatable Tanks, Sound Effects, and Other Audacious Fakery (Book)

multimedia.caption: Gilbert Seltzer in 1942, after graduating from officer candidate school in Fort Belvoir, Va. During World War II he belonged to a secret Army unit, skilled at creating the illusion that American troops were where they weren’t, that came to be known as the Ghost Army.
multimedia.copyright: via Seltzer family

results.title: The U.S. is falling to the lowest vaccination rates of the world’s wealthiest democracies.

results.title: At Pro-Taliban Protest, a Symbol of America’s Lost Influence: Faces Obscured by Veils

results.title: Meeting Hungary’s Strongman, Pope Treads a Fine Line With an Embattled Leader
results.abstract: Pope Francis’ meeting with Viktor Orban could help, or hurt, the prime minister’s efforts to curry favor with voters ahead of coming elections in Hungary, which is predominantly Catholic.

results.title: The ‘Plagiarism Hunter’ Terrorizing the German-Speaking World
results.abstract: Stefan Weber has ended careers, forced politicians from office, hounded scores of others and even created a thriving business in his quest to end literary theft.

multimedia.caption: Stefan Weber, an Austrian communications professor and self-appointed plagiarist hunter, at Mooncity, a museum in Salzburg. His latest prominent target is Annalena Baerbock, the German candidate for chancellor from the Green Party.
multimedia.copyright: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times

results.title: Pfizer and BioNTech will soon seek clearance for vaccine use in children 5 and older.
results.abstract: Results from a study involving 5-to-11-year-olds will be released in the coming weeks, a BioNTech co-founder told Der Spiegel.

results.title: Lebanon Gets New Prime Minister Amid Economic Meltdown
results.abstract: The billionaire Najib Mikati’s new cabinet is Lebanon’s first empowered government in more than a year. It faces the immediate challenge of a collapsing economy.

results.title: Germany Investigates Russia Over Pre-Election Hacking
results.abstract: Berlin has protested to Moscow after identifying repeated attempts to steal politicians’ private information before the election this month that will decide Angela Merkel’s successor.

results.title: Spain Arrests Former Venezuela Spy Chief Accused of Drug Trafficking
results.abstract: Hugo Carvajal, the former intelligence chief, had been hiding in Madrid, the police said, trying to avoid extradition to the United States.

results.title: Bruce Is a Parrot With a Broken Beak. So He Invented a Tool.
results.abstract: The bird is a kea from New Zealand, and his fabrication of an instrument to help him preen his feathers appears to be unique, researchers say.
